content.raw:
Hi Jeff, your changes look good but I'm not sure that the class will work anymore, since there was an additional loop that had to be introduced for compound bases.   Now the arrays returned by the build_matrices method are expected to have 1 higher dimension which indexes the matrices for each sub basis (because in general the expansion of NCCs is different for each sub basis).

Constructing the matrices I think would be so cumbersome at this point to be essentially unusable, and since we can pretty easily inspect the matrices produced by the ParsedProblem for errors, I might be in favor of just removing the old matrix problem class instead of trying to maintain it at the complexity of the parsed problem.  What are your thoughts about this?
content.html:
Hi Jeff, your changes look good but I'm not sure that the class will work anymore, since there was an additional loop that had to be introduced for compound bases. Now the arrays returned by the build_matrices method are expected to have 1 higher dimension which indexes the matrices for each sub basis (because in general the expansion of NCCs is different for each sub basis).

Constructing the matrices I think would be so cumbersome at this point to be essentially unusable, and since we can pretty easily inspect the matrices produced by the ParsedProblem for errors, I might be in favor of just removing the old matrix problem class instead of trying to maintain it at the complexity of the parsed problem. What are your thoughts about this?

content.raw: Yeah, you're probably right. I was thinking this was important scaffolding to keep (both in the sense that it helped us build Dedalus and that I've found it pedagogically useful). But, as you note, making it generic enough to work reliably is very likely more trouble than it's worth. I am leaning toward removing it entirely.
content.html: Yeah, you're probably right. I was thinking this was important scaffolding to keep (both in the sense that it helped us build Dedalus and that I've found it pedagogically useful). But, as you note, making it generic enough to work reliably is very likely more trouble than it's worth. I am leaning toward removing it entirely.

content.raw: Hey Jeff -- I agree with Keaton that it's not worth having a MatrixProblem.  The only reason I can come up with having one is if you're worried that the parser isn't working.  However, given that the parser tells you exactly what matrices it makes for you (problem.equations), I don't see what added benefit you would gain from entering the equations in yourself...  As for the MatrixProblem being pedagogically useful...  I think whenever problems popped up with the MatrixProblem, it would take a long time for me to convince myself that I had entered in the correct equations.  Only then would I consider if the equations I had entered in made any sense.  In that sense, I actually think the ParsedProblem is more pedagogically useful, because I have some faith that it's parsing my equations properly.

content.raw: **UPDATE:** This now removes MatrixProblem, as it is no longer worth maintaining.
